results.t: SPOIL | definition in the Cambridge English Dictionary
SPOIL | definition in the Cambridge English Dictionary
results.p: to destroy or reduce the pleasure, interest, or beauty of something: He tried not to let the bad news spoil his evening. The oil spill has spoiled the whole ...
Spoil, ruin, wreck agree in meaning to reduce the value, quality, usefulness, etc., of anything. Spoil is the general term: to spoil a delicate fabric. Ruin ...
When you spoil something, you destroy it or ruin its quality. If you spoil a surprise, you tell the secret you were supposed to keep.

results.t: SPOIL Synonyms: 247 Similar and Opposite Words
results.p: Some common synonyms of spoil are booty, loot, plunder, prize, and spoils. While all these words mean "something taken from another by force or craft," spoil, ...

results.t: SPOILED | definition in the Cambridge English Dictionary
results.p: 4 days ago — (of a person) treated very well or too well: You're acting like a spoiled brat.

results.t: SPOIL definition and meaning | Collins English Dictionary
results.p: spoil in American English · 1. to damage severely or harm (something), esp. · 2. to diminish or impair the quality of; affect detrimentally · 3. to impair, ...
spoil · destroy · devastate · harm · impair · mar · tarnish · undo · upset · wreck. Strong matches. blemish · damage · debase · deface · defile · demolish ...
1. [+ object] : to have a bad effect on (something) : to damage or ruin (something) The fight spoiled the party. The camping trip was spoiled by bad weather.
1 damage [transitive]SPOIL to have a bad effect on something so that it is no longer attractive, enjoyable, useful etc SYN ruin
